data.title: Multiple RenameProviders for same language issue
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Description:
I would like to have a callback, which is set in an xml file, renamed when I rename the correlating method in my typescript file. So I wrote a custom `RenameProvider` and added it via `c.subscriptions.push(languages.registerRenameProvider({ language: "typescript", scheme: "file", pattern: "**/*.controller.ts" }, new CallbackRenameProvider()));`. 

ut my provider seems to override the result of the `RenameProvider` of the typescript extension. Is there a possibility to have them both coexist? The problem is, if the method is used in another method in the typescript files it will not be renamed there.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Create a custom `RenameProvider` (for example for typescript)
2. Successfully return the `WorkspaceEdit`
3. Rename a method on a class and do some edits somewhere else

**Expected Result:**
The typescript rename provider should rename the symbol in the other file (in my example xml) and the symbol on the typescript class.

**Actual Result:**
The text in the other file does get renamed, but the method name stays the same.
If I deactivate my provider, it does get renamed.
It seems to me my WorkspaceEdit replaces the WorkspaceEdit provided by the typescript extension.

Please let me know, if you need some examples, then I can publish my extension and you can check it out yourself.

For now here is my repo:
https://github.com/apazureck/openui5vscodeTypescriptTools (checkout the develop branch, please)

And here is a test scenario:
https://github.com/apazureck/UI5TypescriptDeclarations/tree/master/generator (master branch)

data.title: vscode.startDebug with type "node" does not work, regardless of protocol
data.body:
"vscode.startDebug" does not respect `type: "node2"` when the configuration supplies `type: "node"`, as it happens in the embedded extension for node.js debugging.

## Background

Visual Studio Code tracing shows that the embedded extension for node.js debugging actually uses `type: "node2"`, even when the auto-generated file "launch.json" provides `type: "node"`. Moreover, `type: "node"` if supplied to the "complex command" "vscode.startDebug" does not work anymore (see steps to reproduce below).

This is very confusing and not documented. The cases of "node2" and "node" should be merged to eliminate "node2". In worst case, this peculiarity should be thoroughly documented.

Related to [24762](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24762).

## Steps to Reproduce:

### 0) Use node.js 8.1.4

### 1) Try node.js debugging with "launch.json":

```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Launch Extension",
            "type": "extensionHost",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${file}",
            "protocol": "auto" // anything but "legacy"
            ],
        }
    ]
}
```
It does work.

### 2) Now, in some extension code:

```
        const launchConfiguration = {
            type: "node", // a real confusion! found by tracing Visual Studio Code
            name: "Launch Extension",
            request: "launch",
            stopOnEntry: false,
            protocol: "auto"
        };
        vscode.commands.executeCommand("vscode.startDebug", launchConfiguration);
```
It shows the error:
> [DEP0062] DeprecationWarning: `node --debug` and `node --debug-brk` are invalid. Please use `node --inspect` or `node --inspect-brk` instead

Even when the protocol is specified explicitly, the problem is the same:

```
        const launchConfiguration = {
            type: "node", // a real confusion! found by tracing Visual Studio Code
            name: "Launch Extension",
            request: "launch",
            stopOnEntry: false,
            protocol: "inspector"
        };
        vscode.commands.executeCommand("vscode.startDebug", launchConfiguration);
```

By documentation and logically, the type "`node`" should work. See also below.

### 3) The workaround:

Change `type: "node"` to `type: "node2"`. It works. But this is not a real solution, because "officially", only `type: "node"` is supported. I do understand that operation with `type: "node2"` may eventually fail with some VSCode update.

## 
Reproduces without extensions: No (the problem appears in extension, more exactly)

data.title: Command to send literal key press to terminal

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Originally https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45257525/ctrlc-inside-vscode-terminal

Inside the integrated terminal, I'd like to be able to make `Ctrl+C`/`Ctrl+V` copy and paste, and have `Ctrl+Shift+C` and `Ctrl+Shift+V` send literal `Ctrl+C`/`Ctrl+V`.

I can do the first two by setting custom key bindings for `workbench.action.terminal.copySelection` and `workbench.action.terminal.paste`.

It looked like maybe I could do the second two using `workbench.action.terminal.sendText`, but when I try it I get `command 'workbench.action.terminal.sendText' not found`, presumably because it's not defined in `terminalActions.ts`.

And if it was available as a command, I'm not sure how I'd pass arguments, or specify control characters.  I would try something like:

       {
            "key": "ctrl+shift+c",
            "command": "workbench.action.terminal.sendText",
            "args": ["\003", false],
            "when": "terminalFocus"
        }

but maybe something more explicit would be better.

data.title: Line unindents when typing in regexp literal (JavaScript)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: 10.12.5

![vsc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50314/28492013-163f9ad0-6efb-11e7-999c-96ef4098b37e.gif)

Steps to Reproduce:

* Have this code:

```javascript
it('something', () => {
  expect(path.basename(appender.fileName)).toMatch(/^dingbat-./);
});
```

* Type `*` inside the regexp.
* Line will be unindented (!).

Also this — same issue, probably:

* Start with this line (indented by _one_ space) as the only contents of the file:

```javascript
 expect(path.basename(appender.fileName)).toMatch(/^dingbat-./);
```

* Try typing `*` inside the regexp. VSCode won't let you (!). It seems related to the fact that the line is the first line in the file.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Autoindent on paste causes wrong indentation (JavaScript)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: 10.12.5

![vsc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50314/28491967-3cbc6464-6efa-11e7-94d0-36c42133fcef.gif)

Steps to Reproduce:

* Take this code:

```javascript
something(() => {

  42;

});
```

* Copy it and try pasting it before the said block.
* The inner lines will be indented too much:

```javascript
something(() => {
  
    42;
  
  });
  something(() => {

  42;

});
```

Notice that the end of the block will also contain an indent.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Configure tasks shows Task creation template when there are provided tasks?
data.body:
vscode smoke test setup https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-smoketest-express.git.

- delete the `task.json` file
- execute Tasks>Run Task -> notice that there are provided tasks
- execute Tasks>Configure Task -> a quick pick with task templates is shown:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/28491313-4fa412b2-6eef-11e7-886d-bea85a9865cc.png)

I would have expected that I can also configure an existing provided task using quick pick with the provided tasks is shown. One option is to have entry in templates section `Customize detected task` that then shows a quick pick with the detected tasks.

- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
vscode-intelephense-client|bme|0.7.2

LogFileHighlighter|emi|1.1.1
vscode-reveal|evi|0.0.9
php-debug|fel|1.11.1
auto-close-tag|for|0.4.3
auto-rename-tag|for|0.0.14
gc-excelviewer|Gra|1.1.15
composer|ika|0.5.0
smarty|imp|0.2.0
code-guid|jam|1.0.1
StretchTimer|jpa|0.0.1
json-to-ts|Mar|1.4.3
Runner|mat|0.1.14
vscode-apache|mrm|1.1.1
cpptools|ms-|0.12.1
github-issues-prs|ms-|0.3.1
php-docblocker|nei|1.2.0
emoji|Per|0.0.3
vscode-versionlens|pfl|0.19.1
datetime|rid|1.0.5
vscode-icons|rob|7.10.1
sharecode|Rol|0.4.1
code-settings-sync|Sha|2.8.2
packagelinker|sin|0.0.3
code-spell-checker|str|1.3.0
lorem-ipsum|Tyr|1.0.0
vscode-arduino|vsc|0.2.4
vscode-todo-highlight|way|0.5.8
highlight-trailing-white-spaces|yba|0.0.2

(2 theme extensions excluded)


---

At the moment, it is not supported having schema.org json-rda `script` tags inside a html file, at least there is no syntax coloring for it. :/

For example:
```html
    <script type="application/ld+json">
        {
            "@context": "http://schema.org",
            "@type": "WebPage",
            "name": "Jens Hausdorf",
            "description": "The website of the {'2002-07-12'|age}-years old developer.",
            "publisher": {
                "@type": "Person",
                "name": "Jens Hausdorf",
                "birthDate": "2002-07-12",
                "email": "hello@jens-hausdorf.de",
                "identifier": "jens1o"
            }
        }
    </script>
```

data.title: Regression: Editing user settings is broken
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (81e812c06540d1bd2636cf70ff7d0edd1bb0e866, 2017-07-21T13:15:10.775Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
project-manager|ale|0.18.1
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
gitlens|eam|4.3.2
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
atom-keybindings|ms-|2.9.1
stylelint|shi|0.28.0

---

When `EditorConfig` extension is installed, editing the user settings is broken. The regression was introduced in e6770ccb29d580670d0384b7bfaba476db6767f3, according to git bisect.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install EditorConfig extension
2. Open the settings `Ctrl+,`
3. Try to type Enter on some line, the new line is inserted, but the cursor remains on the initial line. No Undo as well!
4. Try to type anything, the letters are inserted, but the cursor remains on the same place, which totally breaks the editing. Typing `1`, then `2` and then `3` will end up with `321`

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: Feature Request: < and > history navigation within the active tab
data.body:
I have been using VS Code for a few months now (switched over from Sublime 3), and I have to say that this IDE is really easy to work with and configure! Bravo to the dev team, really appreciate your hard work!

Now, I have Feature Request after having used it for a while:

When you single-click on a file in the project explorer, it will open in the existing tab if no changes have been made to the file or it was not opened with a double-click. When I am navigating about the files in my project, I often only have 1 or 2 files that I am currently editing, several files open in other tabs and one tab that I am using to browse other files. When you have a really long list of files in the explorer, sometimes going back to a file you had open in the tab after <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+`Left Click`ing into a definition or simply browsing a bit can be a PITA.

Opening files like this in the current tab is great to avoid clutter, but wouldn't it be cool if we had Forward `>` and Back `<` text icons that sat in the same bar as the menu, but adjusted to the position of the currently opened tab? Maybe something like this?

![screenshot_20170722_155327](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2549985/28489192-9c62811c-6ef7-11e7-8e90-395c7626862d.png)

data.title: Autoformatting breaks jekyll meta
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:12:01.887Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.11.10-300.fc26.x86_64
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
pgsql|dou|0.0.8
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.6
vscode-sql-beautify|sen|0.0.4



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a .html file to be used with jekyll:
```
--- 
title: My page
---
content goes here
```
2. Save
Expected: stay as entered
Result:
```
--- title: My page ---
content goes here
```


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vs-code-xml-format|fab|0.1.5
ejs-language-support|Qas|0.0.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Put this in a CSS file:
`@import url('mobile.css') (screen and max-width: 700px);`
2. VS Code shows red squiggly underlines

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature request: split gulp build into multiple processes
data.body:
I doubt gulp supports this, but it would be great if the `gulp watch` build task could be split into multiple processes. For example, I imagine the extensions could be built the same time that the rest of the source is built.

Maybe if there was a way, two gulp processes could be spawned, then waited upon before tasks dependent upon those two are run.

This is because on my system, the initial steps before incrementally building the modified typescript files seems to take very long.
